_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



INTRODUCTION



The Entegris facility in Danbury, Connecticut produces Safe Delivery Source® (SDS)® systems to enable safe use of specialty gases, including arsine in the semiconductor industry.  The SDS systems contain the specialty gases on absorbent carbon-based media at sub-atmospheric pressures (< 14.7 psia) in small (0.41 to 6.6 liter) steel cylinders. The regulated processes are simply: 



1.    The transfer of arsine gas from high pressure source cylinders to the SDS cylinders and 

2.    The storage of the high pressure supply source cylinders and filled and empty SDS cylinders.  



No chemical mixing or chemical reactions occur in the process.  Once the gas is transferred to the SDS, it is stored in an inherently safe manner because even if the SDS cylinder were ruptured, the gas would remain on the absorbent media.  The end user must use a vacuum to withdraw the gas from SDS cylinder for use.  



RMP AND PSM THRESHOLDS



The RMP threshold for arsine (1000 pounds) will be triggered because Entegris will be adding additional SDS cylinder storage at the location facility in early 2017.  The OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) threshold for arsine (100 pounds) had been triggered previously, so Entegris already has a PSM program in place.  The PSM program was reviewed as part of the RMP process and recently updated by re-organizing the PSM material making it more readily accessible.  The SDS production and storage process falls within Program 3 of the RMP because the site is subject to PSM and has an offsite public receptor within the worst case scenario release assessment model.  



ARSINE STORAGE AND USE



The facility stores a maximum of seven, 60-pound high pressure steel source cylinders of arsine used to fill the SDS which are stored in a locked hazardous materials storage building that is controlled by an electronic card reader to limit access to trained and authorized personnel.  This area contains gas sensors (Honeywell V

ertex Detection system) and an alarm system that is triggered by detection of arsine gas at a level above the permissible exposure limit (PEL) of 50 ppb.  The high pressure source cylinders arrive with protective steel valve caps that protect the cylinder valves from impact. The source cylinders are checked for leaks upon arrival with portable gas detection equipment.  The high pressure source cylinders contain pneumatic valves which cannot be opened by hand without a special tool. These valves require a pneumatic pressure of 80 psig to open and allow gas to flow from them. In addition the cylinder valve outlet fitting also comes with a sealed protective cap, which would prevent gas flow from the source cylinder if the valve were inadvertently opened. The source cylinder protective valve caps are not removed until the cylinders have been secured inside the gas cabinet and it is time to connect the source cylinder valves to the gas cabinet manifold. The high pressure cylinders are equipped with reduced flow orifices (RFOs) of 0.040 inches which limit the flow of gas from the cylinder when the valve is opened for use.  When placed in service in the gas cabinet, the pneumatic source gas cylinder valve will automatically close at the detection of a gas leak or any building evacuation or fire alarm. The gas cabinet and other related process equipment is ventilated to an emergency release rooftop scrubber (a redundant safety device) which will prevent or minimize a release into the atmosphere outside the building.  The remaining storage of arsine is in the sub-atmospheric pressure SDS cylinders.  



In the event a gas sensor alarm is triggered, the area is evacuated and the Entegris Emergency Response Team (ERT) responds wearing self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA) to determine and remedy the source of the alarm.  If a SDS cylinder or high-pressure cylinder is found to be leaking, the ERT contains it in a gas-tight "coffin" which is safely removed from the facility.

Details of all protections systems are contained within the PSM documentation.



WORST CASE SCENARIO MODEL - TOXICS



RMP*Comp was used to model potential arsine releases from the Entegris facility.  The "Worst Case Release" scenario was based on a catastrophic release of the largest container at the facility, the 60 pound high pressure arsine source cylinder.  The following offsite consequence analysis parameters were used, as dictated by 40 CFR 68.22.  



?    Release of entire contents of 60 pound source cylinder in a 10 minute period for a release rate of 6 pound/minute;

?    Wind Speed of 1.5 meters per second

?    Class F atmospheric stability 

?    Ground level release

?    Air temperature of 77 degrees F

?    Urban surroundings



Using the above parameters, the affected area was computed to encompass a 1.6 mile radius around the facility.  



ALTERATIVE SCENARIO MODEL - TOXICS



The alternative scenario is intended to be a more likely scenario than a sudden catastrophic release of the largest container.  For this scenario, it was assumed that one of the high pressure arsine source cylinders was left wide open.  The flow rate would be based on the flow through the 0.040" RFO.  Entegris has computed this to be 93.5 liters per minute  (=3.302 cubic feet per minute) with a density of 0.2 pounds per cubic foot  which equals 0.66 pounds/minute.  Entegris has reported that it would take the ERT much less than 60 minutes to don SCBA and contain such a leak from a high pressure source cylinder.  So, the alternative scenario was to assume a release rate of 0.66 pounds per minute for a period of 60 minutes.  



Other assumptions were based on the default parameters for an alternative scenario in RMP*Comp.  These include:



?    Wind Speed of 3 meters per second

?    Class D atmospheric stability 

?    Ground level release

?    Air temperature of 77 degrees F

?    Urban surroundings



Using RMP*comp, this resulted in a potentially affected area within a 0.2 mile radius around the g

as storage area at Entegris.  



RELEASE SCENARIOS - FLAMMABLE GAS

    

Arsine is not considered a flammable gas in the RMP program, so flammable gas releases were not evaluated.  



EVALUATION OF POTENTIAL RELEASE AREAS



The potential release areas were evaluated in two ways:  



For the 0.2 mile radius, a windshield survey was conducted on each street within the affected area and recording the entities within that area.  The area was entirely light industrial and commercial, with no residences, schools, prisons, or hospitals in that radius.  The only public receptors are an industrial/office area a small shopping center containing a grocery store and other retail and service establishments in the alternative scenario area.  



The 1.6 mile radius contained a larger portion of Danbury and a portion of Bethel, Connecticut, but would only be affected under a very unusual circumstance such as the entire head of the source cylinder being sheared off.  Based on CAMEO Marplot software, the area contains a residential population of 19,000.  It also contains the following resources:



?    Schools

?    Recreation Area

?    Hospital

?    Commercial, office and industrial areas



It is not expected that either scenario would occur, and Entegris's five year history has no significant releases outside their facility and no injuries.  





PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS (PHA)



Entegris has completed, and recently updated a PHA using a "What if" technique that includes.  This organized and systematic effort identified more than 140 potential hazards and focused on equipment, instrumentation, utilities, human actions (routine and non-routine), and external factors that might impact the process.  It was conducted by engineers, scientists and technicians familiar with the process and equipment.  



Some of the key hazards and the way in which they are mitigated are identified in the excerpts below:



?    Potential Hazard and Solution: High pressure arsine gas leak outside of gas cabinet

(into room air). This is unlikely scenario as all high pressure gases are stored in areas monitored by the Vertex and any leaks > PEL would trigger an evacuation alarm. All high pressure source cylinders are immediately checked for leaks with portable gas detection equipment when source cylinders arrive from the vendor in shipping and receiving. The high pressure source cylinders are then moved out of Receiving and into the outdoor Hazmat shed to minimize any potential impact to the source cylinders by a forklift in Shipping and Receiving. High pressure source cylinders arrive with protective steel valve caps that protect the cylinder valves from impact. The high pressure source cylinders contain pneumatic valves which cannot be opened by hand without a special tool. These valves require a pneumatic pressure of 80 psig to open and allow gas to flow from them. The source cylinder protective valve caps are not removed until the source cylinders have been secured inside the gas cabinet and it is time to connect the cylinder valves to the gas cabinet manifold. In addition the source cylinder valve outlet fitting also comes with a sealed protective cap, which would prevent gas flow from the cylinder if the valve were inadvertently opened. However if this situation does occur, personnel will immediately evacuate the area and leave the building and activate the building evacuation alarm as they leave. The operator of the plant should immediately apprise the ERT of the hazard condition if possible. Affected persons will seek medical attention immediately if there was any exposure to the gas.

?    Potential Hazard and Solution: Fire in plant. The entire process area is covered by a sprinkler system and each gas cabinet has its own internal sprinkler head installed at the top. Activation of any sprinkler head or smoke detector would automatically trigger a fire alarm.  Any person discovering a fire will inform area occupants and actuate any plant emergency off switch if readily

accessible and immediately evacuate the area and the building and activate the fire alarm while exiting the building. The operator of the plant should immediately apprise an ERT member of the hazard condition if possible.

?    Potential Hazard and Solution: Toxic gas leak from Vacuum Pump. Arsine vacuum pump stands are enclosed and monitored with the toxic gas monitors. Vacuum pumps are helium leak checked at the manufacturer's site upon purchase of a new pump or after completion of maintenance and repair by the manufacturer to prevent such leaks.  



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Entegris has had no accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



PREVENTION PROGRAM DESCRIPTION



Entegris makes Safe Delivery Source® systems for highly toxic materials and therefore is highly regulated for safety and has an active and wide-reaching Prevention Program.  The Danbury site has an approved Site Security Plan regulated by the Department of Homeland Security Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism standard and ISO 14000 and OHSAS 18001 standard certifications.  As a result of a recent Process Safety Management (PSM) audit, much of the program has been updated and reorganized to make information readily accessible.  The core of the program is SDS Hydride Safety Review which has been recently updated. It contains links to many of the PSM requirements and has sections/links that include but are not limited to the following:



?    Process Safety Information

?    Process Technology Information

?    Process Equipment Information

?    Process Flow Diagram and Process & Instrumentation Diagrams

?    Process Hazard Analysis

?    Operating Procedures

?    Employee Training 

?    Start-Up Review

?    Contractor Work Requirements (Contractor Safety Performance is ongoing and will be complete by February 28, 2017)

?    Inspecti

ons, Calibrations and Preventive Maintenance

?    Management of Change

?    Incident Prevention



The document is maintained electronically in Entegris' ISO 14000 and OHSAS 18001 Management System and updated as needed due to facility or other changes and/or when required by regulation.  



EMERGENCY RESPONSE



Entegris maintains both an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) and has an on-site Emergency Response Team to respond to site incidents.  The ERP has been recently updated and includes:



?    ERT Command Structure and Responsibilities

?    General Emergency Response Procedures

?    Training

?    Maintenance and Review of ERP

?    Local, State and Federal Emergency Contacts

?    Medical Facility Location



The document is maintained electronically in Entegris' ISO 14000 and OHSAS 18001 Management System and updated as needed due to facility or other changes and/or when required by regulation.
